topic.title: What happened to ZeroBoard?
topic.body: [ZeroBoard](/Board.ZeroNetwork.bit/) does not show any messages and doesn't seem to contain user data. Is it broken?

topic.title: Norwegian Police child porn honeypot in Direct Connect network
topic.body:
Norwegian Police set up a honeypot with fake files with child porn names using police IP address range in Direct Connect network (DC/DC++).

[/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/data/users/1EtunFAaE5bnDSjWSSsCkxAu7EYikL56Um/src/2cdf1127c1e0d987e7d9805c5bdc87fc5d53b31c.png](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/data/users/1EtunFAaE5bnDSjWSSsCkxAu7EYikL56Um/src/2cdf1127c1e0d987e7d9805c5bdc87fc5d53b31c.png)

This is what you get when you download any file:

[/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/data/users/1EtunFAaE5bnDSjWSSsCkxAu7EYikL56Um/src/a15c42a3831bce8c5ba92d21bd6ef5e8d66cbeeb.jpg](/1ADQAHsqsie5PBeQhQgjcKmUu3qdPFg6aA/data/users/1EtunFAaE5bnDSjWSSsCkxAu7EYikL56Um/src/a15c42a3831bce8c5ba92d21bd6ef5e8d66cbeeb.jpg)

topic.title: ZeroNet bug: incorrect language variable expansion in GET request
topic.body:
@nofish

Several Zites, including ZeroHello and ZeroTalk, perform the following GET request (or similar, the problem is the same):

`http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/js/all.js?lang={lang}`

That is, with `lang={lang}`.
Modern web browsers send curly brackets in GET parameter value unquoted, while some parsers (Java) do not expect that.

Is that non-expanded variable a bug or a feature? Could it be fixed?

topic.title: Live video streaming zite example
topic.body:
Here's an example of live video streaming in ZeroNet:

[/1GVnY2gwrqXRsnYcpNtQQtri6ezqCKY2im/](/1GVnY2gwrqXRsnYcpNtQQtri6ezqCKY2im/)

This zite uses [clappr](http://clappr.io/) video player library which loads HLS video stream, which is pushed to ZeroNet (signed & published) every 30 seconds.
Video files are marked as optional, while playlist is not.

topic.title: TiddlyWiki ZeroNet support: compatibility fix and a saver plugin
topic.body:
[TiddlyWiki](https://tiddlywiki.com/) is an in-browser wiki engine written in JavaScript which runs entirely in your browser and does not require a server. I made ZeroNet compatibility plugin which allows saving wiki data on ZeroNet using only your browser, without re-uploading TiddlyWiki file manually.

If you're not familiar with TiddlyWiki, read [interactive introduction to TiddlyWiki](https://tiddlywiki.com/editions/introduction/) or check out [the presentation](https://tiddlywiki.com/talkytalky/). Also visit [its homepage](https://tiddlywiki.com/) for more information.

Now you can use TiddlyWiki for your ZeroNet zites.

[TiddlyWiki on ZeroNet](/1MVyVRFfQ8nSR3dMxisz1pZBwrd8jJRezy/)

1552725050_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:

To learn more about git, visit: https://git-scm.com/ and https://github.com/

1552767554_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body: If firewall blocks this port, or if you're behind NAT, no peers would be able to connect to you. This greatly reduces connectivity, thus zite availability.

1552788873_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
Can anyone explain like i'm an autist, why they do this? Why shouldn't the video be shared, why people better not to watch that, why should people be prosecuted for possessing and sharing it?
It looks like the reason is quite clear for anyone, and it really puzzles me.

> [quantumkitty](#comment_207_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEaQbNZu): I'm guessing it might trigger some people who are sensitive to that content. Which is understandable.Â Then again, the sheer nature of the content is such that it tempts people to watch it, because the human mind is morbidly curious.Â Still. The punishment doesn't fit the crime.

Do you mean that watching the video may provoke others to do the same? TV channels show car accidents, and it is unlikely they provoke someone IMO.

I don't understand why this _should_ be punishable in the first place. How can this be illegal? I showed this video to my patents and friends right after I downloaded it, and explained that it's not only about terrorism, it's also 100% media-aware: the shooter had a portable speaker with meme songs only chan visitors would understand, with timed playlist; funny manifesto which also full of copypaste and memes.

Why 9/11 video was played on all major channels and TV programs from different angles, yet THIS video should be banned?

1552807915_1CBZY3cuYKeHZXEeHVxRFLmsCr3Um.body: There's no "server side" (=php) code in ZeroNet, all user code is executed in browser and contain in .js files. The databases are user readable.

> [eighty4](#comment_1_1CBZY3cuYKeHZXEeHVxRFLmsCr3UmELnTX): So things like private chats and such are impossible?

It's possible but with additional protection measures. For example, you can use client-side message encryption. All the data will be still available for everyone, but it's all encrypted and can't be read by third-party.

> [malladis](#comment_1_18bPiPS2hgoc8pbS8Ku8aoWQ748jfC6vkV): Right, so basically it's impossible to run a site like Reddit/Facebook/Twitter etc. [...]

It's possible. It's implemented by so-called merger plugin which can connect (join) remote zites into current zite. Merger zites are usually created per-user, per-account or in a similar way, so you download and seed only data you are interested in.

Take a look at [ZeroMe](/Me.ZeroNetwork.bit/) (Twitter alternative) or [ZeroMedium](/ZeroMedium.bit/) (medium.com alternative).

1552858206_1NZftAz9VSawGF5JgMYGFv4ByoKEa.body:
>The fact that it's based on an overly hyped technology that seemed very promising and revolutionary in the beginning (blockchain), but ultimately fell short of people's expectations and disappointed the world in 2018.

But ZeroNet is not based on Blockchain.

>The fact that you have to download a zip file to be able to access it.

Go and set up inproxy (Internet â†’ ZeroNet proxy).
Actually, I'm puzzled on why there are so many IPFS proxies (even by huge companies like Cloudflare), yet there's only one open ZeroNet proxy I know: 0net.io.

Automatic video encoding may be possible in modern browsers with webassembly. It was possible long before webassembly with EmScripten+asm.js (see [ffmpeg.js](https://github.com/Kagami/ffmpeg.js/)), but it's relatively slow.

> [toyata](#comment_55_17mM4YqSx7nMkYcePZB2GWcJBzkogWpqA1): Maybe one idea is to link to allow and only one specific zite without the "0" at top corner? So people then only see e.g. ZeroTalk linked to e.g. clearnet talk.zeroportal.io?And on startpage zeroportal introduce those pages linked.

I thought about that and proposed to implement special DNS record, see https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/391#issuecomment-435372284

1552916412_1GDzVsFoYamHqWcYBcuvVWFCAt3Y5.body: The principle is somewhat similar to Tor onion routing. Yes, it's considered to be secure at current time.

> [i2pxmr](#comment_3_1PQQRjVa9rQXnDrWxPPqwroBRroz5F6DFh): Tor was not designed to run with bittorrent. By using bittorent over Tor, you are hurting the Tor network.

This is hoax. When Tor developers say that Tor should not be used with Bittorrent, they refer to usual Bittorrent clients which will connect only to clearnet nodes, hurting Exit Node bandwidth.

1552994065_14JMe2K9H9F9DwFi2s6tuwiQT66FY.body:
> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_732_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): where to get "signer address" mentioned on that page? Is it user's public key? in my case 1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS (when you hover over my username near my post)? [...]

Signer address is a random bitcoin key, as far as I understand.
Another person need to generate additional bitcoin address, open the zite, pull "0" to the left, set a tick on "this is my website", press "Add saved private key", copy-paste bitcoin private address.
This person gives to you (the zite owner) public bitcoin address, you add it into signers_sign/signs_required and public changes.
After this, both persons are zite owners.

1553103471_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:

It heavily relied on a backend server, that would receive the posts and sign and publish them. Nofish said a few months(I think) back, that he was planning to pull the plug at some point.So I think that's just what happened.

I had a feeling that ZeroBoard used client-server architecture but didn't dive into the code to check that.
NoFish could at least leave a message that the board is now longer works.

1553079752_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26c.body:
Try to set the following before running ZeroNet, it may help on OpenVZ:
ulimit -s 1024

@60, how are you going to handle abuse messages? There were several ZeroNet gateways but they didn't last long generally because of CP and such.

There is https://proxy.zeronet.a0z.ru/ by Balancer, but he died several months ago, and I'm not sure what's going to happen with this proxy.

> [60](#comment_50_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26cQmCD1): did you mean he died physically or he stopped getting online anymore? [...]

He died physically.
[/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:45](/1BLoGBTid3NhGu8ts3fAfHJprnbrH3wfTV/?Post:45)

> [60](#comment_50_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26cQmCD1): and for the cp metter, they don't really care about zn

What I wanted to say is that if you allow every zite on your gateway, sooner or later somebody will open child pornography zites and report links for the images/videos/pages/etc to your hoster. You hoster most probably will suspend or terminate your gateway.

Balancer avoided it by blocking new zites. Only known zites added by him are allowed on proxy.zeronet.a0z.ru.

> [ssdifnskdjfnsdjk](#comment_760_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnXadUtS): i think many hosters first notice client and you have to take down content in 24 hours. True that i do not have experience with child p0rn, that content is rare. For peace of mind, you may ask your hoster what they do in case of report. If the risk is too big, you can disable adding new sites and remove ones that can host user submitted content like millchan, kopykate..

I don't have any public gateways, but I do have a VPN service, which may be compared with a lite version of Tor exit node. Most abuse messages I get are DMCA copyright violations which require little to no action in most jurisdictions. Sometimes I get more serious messages, like someone used VPN to scan RDP servers, hacked into one of them and uploaded a ransomware cryptolocker which encrypted files on the server.

Anyway, by running public gateway, you're not only host the files (let's say child porn here) but also freely distribute it. I would recommend @60 to make a zite which will briefly describe how ZeroNet works, what this site (=gateway) work exactly, leave an abuse contact and set it as a ZeroNet homepage for it to open as a main page.

> [60](#comment_52_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26cQmCD1): i'm gonna do this by modding the uipassword plugin

You can just set the homepage, use `--homepage` CLI flag or set it in `zeronet.conf`.

> [60](#comment_53_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26cQmCD1): by doing so, zerohello wont be able to list sites

Huh, why? It works for me.

> [60](#comment_54_1Ekf2tGQLhG3iifFsuUk9RcBPx26cQmCD1): idk, and do you have something like a porn list?it's quite complicated to manually pick them out and block them

No, I don't have it. Remember that new porn sites may appear any time.

1553166302_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:
> [pexo](#comment_72_1DfrA2M9Qra6stqT6tzwNMYNweswY54KAC): [...]

I was interested in what kind of IP ranges/internet connections people with CP in DC++ use, and the first IP address I tried to whois was Norwegian Police. That heighten my interest, I captured lots of IP addresses for lots of queries, and it turns out that overwhelming majority are usual home users with home internet connection. I found only two servers (in datacenter) and Norwegian police which are not home users.

1553193009_1KHWybGXJ9cwqzANezSfXbrEq9sgS.body:
> [gabew](#comment_4_1PZnbAYUg4AzDgJU4gtTupekoaNp1Mwizi): Does ZeroNet work on I2P?

Not really yet. It can't utilize I2P connectivity, but it can be set up as a gate (and there is one, http://zeronet.i2p)

Tor has several types of censorship circumvention. Meek that uses Amazon infrastructure as a proxy, Snowflake which uses other users browser(!) connection, etc. It's rather hard to block Tor for a generic European country which is not known for censorship, although such countries as China and Turkmenistan block Tor and almost all Tor bridges, Tor is very unreliable there.

I can write some insides about Russia and Turkmenistan censorship methods if anyone is interested in that.

1554025779_193rzuH9AAHfvHKwSFS5oq6jRpXwD.body:
https://www.tahoe-lafs.org/

Tahoe-LAFS is a Free and Open decentralized cloud storage system. It distributes your data across multiple servers. Even if some of the servers fail or are taken over by an attacker, the entire file store continues to function correctly, preserving your privacy and security.

1554160326_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5.body:
Works fine for me in Firefox 66.0.1 and Chromium 71.0.3578.98.
Do you run ZeroNet on Windows?
Run:
`curl -I http://127.0.0.1:43110/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/data/users/131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs/1553882551-stig.revealed.webp`
And post here execution result.

If you use Windows, I suppose the problem is in MIME type (`Content-Type` header). I get `image/webp` on Linux.

> [klu9](#comment_138_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): I downloaded & unzipped cURL for Windows, and eventually worked out how to do it.curl -I http://127.0.0.1:4 [...]

So yes, the problem is with MIME type on Windows. `application/octet-stream` is not a proper MIME type for webp. I'll file an issue in ZeroNet.

> [klu9](#comment_140_131Seivv6aH8vnohPmYPcPwPfZ1a5ubMMs): Maybe content type is an issue with mhtml being treated as a download rather than a type of web page to open.curl -I http://127.0.0.1:4 [...]

Try renaming .mhtml to .mht

1554322767_1MTNhSVgCJpW8uBjFhnyA5NsgyKbK.body: ZeroNet mirrors of clearnet websites are usually done by downloading the website and hosting static downloaded html pages inside ZeroNet.

1555148481_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
As for 13.04.2019, Russia does not block Tor, I2P, ShadowSocks or VPN (either providers or protocols), however it block web proxies (also known as anonymizers) and some usual public and private proxies which are known for being used for proxying Telegram. The latter is done with some sort of automatic system, probably by dumping [netflow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NetFlow) or the traffic itself of one or several ISPs, and testing each remote host if it's HTTP/Socks/MTPROTO proxy.

There's no global or unified DPI system in Russia, different ISP use different methods of blocking. Some use commercial solutions from vendors, some make their own DPI, some use open source systems, some just block by IP address using routing tables on routers.

The list of blocked websites and IP addresses is available on https://reestr.rublacklist.net/, more information in English in available on https://usher2.club/en/, but it's a bit outdated and biased.

1555253500_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:
> [nofish](#comment_1267_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): It was an optimization (skipped the variable replace when the language is en), but thanks for reporting I have removed it in Rev4068 (Py3 version)

Thanks, backported this modification to Python2 version, works as expected. Should I make a pull request?

1555484698_1FPWnVYRbYfj96dvxSPx5hwtt2C8X.body:
> [caryoscelus](#comment_124_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): I don't believe media streaming is currently possible, unless maybe some plugin supports it (but i've never seen anyone advertising such a plugin)

I'm pretty sure you can do HLS live streaming using any media server (nginx with nginx-rtmp plugin as an example). You need to call Zeronet's SignAndPublish on every playlist update.

1555521255_1ME9gwj9Exp9cBbuSxxr1mEiySEjm.body: There's [ZeroUp Unlimited](/1CiXRY9ATZSoZqBzwMfXEMsKtPRt2aQoF2/), which allows to upload small files as well.

1555652637_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:
> [robione](#comment_220_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): So it's not live? It's a video already on disk.

It's live. It's streamed and re-encoded realtime, then cut into chunks and pushed into ZeroNet.

> [caryoscelus](#comment_130_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): So yeah, sometimes it starts working, but then goes down again. I don't think i got any "streaming" behaviour past one chunk.

I've increased chunks amount, try it in 3 minutes. But yeah, it works fine as long as it can push data directly to peers, but if you don't have direct connectivity, of it there's just more than 5 peers, other peers does not push content as fast as I expected.
All right, let's try with video chunks as optional files.

> [gluek](#comment_18_1LsU5cS8D3qjVLzgdwtcfdXtHEY8T2Gixi): It's work for few seconds, than don't load more. And it's always same video fragment after reloading page.

ffmpeg crashed, try again.

> [caryoscelus](#comment_131_13oRBYqNeUr6Tvgt4KkAT9FT4XRiKFBjnE): Seems to work now. Good job ;) [...]

It doesn't. Video pieces are optional files.

> [robione](#comment_222_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): So it's streaming from the files, not from another video source or device (phone, camera, pc)?? [...]

You can stream from any video source. This is not a video on demand, this is live streaming, but with 1-2 minutes delay. It doesn't matter if it's from files or web camera.

Video streaming itself is out of ZeroNet scope, you need some external software to encode video and save it into HLS-compliant format into ZeroNet folder.

I'm using ffmpeg to stream to HLS. The command is as follows:
`ffmpeg -re -fflags genpts -f concat -safe 0 -r 24000/1001 -i ~/zeronet-streaming/playlist_random.txt -map v:0 -map a:0 -f hls -hls_time 30 -hls_list_size 3 -hls_delete_threshold 3 -hls_flags delete_segments -c:v libx264 -vf scale=960x540 -preset fast -crf 25 -g 72 -c:a libmp3lame -b:a 192k -ac 44100 -r 24000/1001 video.m3u8`

And then publish changes to ZeroNet every 30 seconds in browser.
You can supply RTMP stream, to re-stream something into ZeroNet, or configure to stream your screen, or you can use OBS.

> [leftside](#comment_724_16dEowtNbV89NxPcDrAKkmnuXtiJVoVcDm): How did u sign&publish every 30 seconds??

I made a timer on the page. If you're the site owner, there will be a prompt to supply private key for the site. See index.html source.

@leftside, delay is from 30 seconds to 2 minutes, it depends on HLS configuration. ZeroNet by default will publish zite not faster than every 30 seconds, so it's not possible to publish HLS playlist and pieces faster than every 30 seconds without ZeroNet source hacking.

Anyway, this was a proof of concept for @blackmoon, it has proven to work pretty fine. The stream is now offline.

> [robione](#comment_223_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): Very cool, with one minor squibble on the 'live' aspect in which delay is tolerated in seconds, but not minutes. [...]

Check [StreamZ](http://127.0.0.1:43110/Talk.ZeroNetwork.bit/?Topic:1555759517_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di/StreamZ), it has much less delay.

> [nickwa](#comment_113_1EFZ3dYDWVpD4kF5H9PF83HjPAehEEKKJj): Looks interesting. I always wanted a live streaming zite. Hope that you get success.

You can clone it, run ffmpeg command which generates HLS stream (look at example below) and it will work.

1555759517_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body:

1559028625_1HEBittLV8ADkGMhNehgZKsciCokp.body:
For HTML5 video in browser you'll need to either use WebM with VP8/VP9 video and Vorbis/Opus audio, or MP4 H.264, with MOOV atom in the beginning of the file (so-called "fast start").

Use: `ffmpeg -i input.avi -map v:0 -map a:0 -c:v libx264 -crf 22 -c:a aac -b:a 192k -movflags faststart -pix_fmt yuv420p output.mp4`

1566230571_1LGApmQZPN49nawg4HQQgf8ToVUPx.body:
> [gitcenter](#comment_620_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Is it like cloning ZeroWiki and not sharing it?

Sorry, I don't get the question. TiddlyWiki is a stand-alone wiki engine, it's not a fork of ZeroWiki. It could be used for public or private "installations" even on ZeroNet, there's build in encryption with password protection.

Also, TiddlyWiki is a very flexible engine. [This](https://tiddlywiki.com/talkytalky/) presentation is running on TiddlyWiki! People also use it [as a blog engine](https://jermolene.com/) or even as [GTD](http://cardo.wiki/)

> [gitcenter](#comment_621_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di)

Unfortunately, I'm not familiar with ZeroWiki, but TiddlyWiki is more than just a wiki. It contains a very flexible wikitext parser, you can write your own code inside it. There's plugins and themes support, you can download it right from the wiki itself.

Of course you can use it as your personal wiki or for notes/blog, as well as you can use it for public wiki/website.

You can export TiddlyWiki pages as .html or generate a full static site, too. Take a look at https://teclast-m89.neocities.org/

> [gitcenter](#comment_622_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Huh, that looks like a more powerful tool than I expected. Thanks for porting it to ZeroNet!

There are some plugins for third-party comment systems already available. I'll try re-use them to implement similar comment system using ZeroNet only, as another plugin, or maybe even make wiki editing functionality by other ZeroNet users like it's implemented in ZeroWiki. But for now, only owner can edit TiddlyWiki.

There are some compatibility issues still present, I'll try to fix them or ask Tamas for ZeroNet code fix.

> [kaffie](#comment_1048_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): The site says to clone it to have a personal copy, but the cloning option is not enabled.

Indeed. Fixed it, thanks.
UPD: reverted it back to prevent users from rewriting their wikis with "upgrade code" button.

> [aspidochelone](#comment_114_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): Is it possible to use TiddlyWiki to compile a "Best of ZeroTalk" page â€¦

Do you want to make this page manually or to generate one? You can use Tiddlywiki to do that manually, that's for sure, but it would require some programming skills to make it generate itself.

> [kaffie](#comment_1066_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): I'm not quite sure what the solution is. look at zeroblog for how to make the upgrade code button not overwrite data.

TiddlyWiki is a single HTML (index.html) file, it doesn't store data in different files, it re-generates itself on every save.

I've tested several methods to enable cloning but not to rewrite index.html, and all of them failed. Do you have an idea how to implement that?

> [aspidochelone](#comment_125_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsKABo1Z): I was assuming it would be manual or semi-automated (like dragging links or something).  I have no idea, I scarcely know ZeroNet let alone the other.

You can do that manually, it's just a wiki. It also supports scripting in it's own scripting language and in JavaScript.

> [kaffie](#comment_1071_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): Content should be separated from the platform that's loading it. If all of it is in the index.html, how would you update it without rewriting the index.html file?

You can't, and you don't need to. TiddlyWiki is a self-contained document, even the pictures are embedded into this single html by default. To update it, you [open a special upgrading TiddlyWiki](https://tiddlywiki.com/upgrade.html), drag your current HTML file into it and it generates updated version of the HTML.

This concept was invented by TiddlyWiki authors, not by me.

1566479582_1PPUrYcZ1E1rGkkE6PH18Qi43LRsK.body:
>I feel what we need is something more like (a) "some guy who has a dictionary file you can edit", (b) times 1000

Check out how I2P domain name system is implemented. Basically, every node has it's own "hosts" file which merges records from different sources (other different hosts files).

There are "domain registrars": a services which add your record to their hosts file, which other node can use for merging into their own file.

1566642594_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2.body: Wait-wait-wait, you shouldn't use existence TLDs! Please do not use .it, .me, .to, .info, .net, .sh, domains! This creates collision with real DNS domains and records!

> [kaffie](#comment_1085_1NWh3WAty57FH8at1WtrZigMrdhrDkuPzh): That's what I said lol. fortunately zn addresses are still prefixed with localhost:port, and/or /zero/

I'm planning to contribute the plugin which gets ZeroNet address from a real DNS record, just like it's implemented in IPFS, and it won't work with Name.IT plugin installed since it would create a collision.
Using existing domain zones is a bad idea by all means.

> [gitcenter](#comment_739_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): The point is that clearnet services shouldn't be the only way to create domains.

That's totally OK if you use your own domain zones which are not used and registered. Something unique and very unlikely to be registered officially in the future, like .zeronet (.zn is probably fine too).

> [gitcenter](#comment_739_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): The point is that clearnet services shouldn't be the only way to create domains.

Take a look what NameCoin, EmerDNS, I2P, Tor did: they made their own domain zones. That is a proper way to run your own domain zones.

> [gitcenter](#comment_741_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Would you, like, replace name.it with name.it.zn then?

Yes. I'd prefer `.name.it.zeronet` since `.zeronet` is a searchable word and you can just publish such domain in clearnet without additional information and people would understand where they should open it.
Additionally, I think you should check that the website is exist, up and running before adding it to the database. At least check if it's a valid Bitcoin address.

> [gitcenter](#comment_742_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): Looks like you're missing the point. .bit domains aren't for ZeroNet only, as well as Bitcoin addresses aren't for ZeroNet only. So ZeroNet should use use domainname.bit.zeronet and addr.zeronet. But then, why doesn't domainname.it.zeronet work?

No, unfortunately you're missing the point here.

`.bit` domains could be used in ZeroNet because they __may__ contain a special record with ZeroNet address inside the domain information, just like with regular domains. They __may__ contain real IPv4/IPv6 addresses, MX records etc as well. `.bit` domains are consistent: once you registered `.bit` domain, you control it in both clearnet and in ZeroNet (since ZeroNet does not "implement" `.bit` domains but sync it with a real NameCoin database). In your plugin, the owner of `name.it` DNS name can't control `name.it` inside ZeroNet with your plugin.

Imagine if ZeroNet could query such records for a real DNS domains, so you can open e.g. `127.0.0.1:43110/zeronet.io/` and it would open. ZeroNet queries real `zeronet.io` domain over DNS, gets a TXT record which contains ZeroNet address and opens the website.
By using real DNS zones, your plugin creates conflict with real existing DNS records and prevents implementing this functionality in the future.
I'd propose using `.zeronet` zone. Just wipe all existing data, this is a test anyway.
Hrm, you have a correct point. `.nameit`, then?
`.zname`, `.znet`. I personally like `.nameit` because it's clear that you need "Name.IT plugin" for `.nameit` domain.
That's fine I guess. New two-character domain zone is unlikely to be registered in the future.

Definitely better than it used to be.

FYI, this is the list of the third-party domain zones I'm aware of:
`'bbs.', 'chan.', 'cyb.', 'dyn.', 'geek.', 'gopher.', 'indy.', 'libre.', 'neo.', 'null.', 'o.', 'oss.', 'oz.', 'parody.', 'pirate.', 'free.', 'bazar.', 'coin.', 'emc.', 'lib.', 'fur.', 'bit.', 'ku.', 'te.', 'ti.', 'uu.'`

It's NameCoin + EmerDNS + OpenNIC + New Nations
More information: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_DNS_root
I don't see problems with current domains.

1566746537_1GP1GwsgiyybaHxGxfTEbsMCqRS9o.body:
Open `data/1TaLkFrMwvbNsooF4ioKAY9EuxTBTjipT/js/all.js`

Line 1071
Find:
`      return btoa(unescape(encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(obj, void 0, '\t'))));`
Replace with:
`      return btoa(unescape(encodeURIComponent(JSON.stringify(obj, void 0, false))));`

This will re-format your .json file without spaces, which will save some kilobytes of space.

1567130399_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qk.body:
> [ratsmack](#comment_42_16BaY5JLzzA8TPe4jzXtp3CfZi3Qks2SU5): but I couldn't find an explanation of how ZeroNet determined when to use Tor and when not to.

As far as I understand, the peer publishes different addresses to the tracker. In case of "Tor: available", ZeroNet would first use IPv4 and IPv6 addresses and if that fails, an onion address.

1570416195_12tcdM86TcZQeHEsSea3kTdTiExBK.body:
Systemd is the best what has happened with Linux in last 10 years. I'm absolutely serious.

It was so exhausting to write shitty shell init scripts, which were a little bit different in any major distro (you couldn't reuse Debian init script in Fedora of that time for example). They didn't support run order, they didn't support isolation, log redirection, nothing. If you want to slightly modify the script, you had to copy it, edit and support your own init script copy!

With systemd everything mentioned above is super easy. With systemd we finally have daemon filesystem, syscall and capability isolation, at least for the most important daemons. You can apply CPU and memory limits. You can configure the daemon to restart if it crashes. With journald you can finally read the daemon's output right in `systemctl status`, you don't have to `tail /var/log/something/where/is/that/log/file/dammit.txt` to see what's wrong and why it doesn't start.

I just don't get it when randomly complain about systemd, like your post, @kanade. systemd has it's own problems and drawbacks, sure, but it's much better than anything which was before it.

1570901775_1L4dZcDF2maSKHDy788yhxpYnBWnX.body:
The original website is http://spyware.neocities.org/
I think that the author's definition of spyware is nonsense and most of his classification methods are not how you would really analyze the program to make a definitive verdict.

I tried to contact the author to add something about Thunderbird but got no reply, and there's no changes on the page.

There's another somewhat similar project, from digdeeper: https://digdeeper.neocities.org/. I argued digdeeper's spyware definition too; he believes that if the software performs **any** unsolicited request to the internet then it's a privacy threat and should be classified as a spyware.

The community of digdeeper seems actually nice, but they use public XMPP chat with OMEMO encryption enabled, which is not supported and just doesn't work as expected. It's explicitly unsupported on some clients (Conversations for example) and is also unsupported in Gajim, digdeeper's recommended client, due to bug in software. To read the messages and to be able to post, you need to add every chat participant to XMPP roster manually, and do that every time new participant connects. Moreover, due to another bug in Gajim, you don't see content not encrypted for you, and you don't even know there are messages you can't see. I laughed at them all at first, tried to hang in a chat group for several days and have a chat, but then had to leave because they are using technologies in an unsupported way to create artificial barrier for something as simple as a public chat.

1590041703_19y1ZG2DVeRM65kYxKcLz7MLGTfTf.body:
> So WHY does Russia have so many openly illegal websites!? 

Can you name a few? I don't remember seeing CP on Russian websites like in a 10 years. Russia now have pretty strict laws regarding information on the internet, especially pornography, which is prohibited for creation and distribution.

Generally CP in Russia became a kind of subculture/meme thing, but it's meme popularity is on the wane.

In the 90s and early 00s there were several CP studios in Ukraine and Russia. Some of them worked with waifs/orphans because many orphanages were poor at that time and children were seeking for a better life/money. Some of them were building trust between children, which is the case of single-person 1st studio of Novosibirsk, where arguably the most recognisable CP "star" was born: Masha Babko, whos photos and videos have been uploaded to the internet, presumably by someone involved in the arrest or investigation process.
Somewhere around 5 years ago you could spot a meme macrosses like "that feeling when you stump your feet" with cropped face of Masha, and "Ð¦ÐŸ Ð² Ð›Ð¡" ([send] CP to PM) was a catchphrase which you could spot even written on a construction site fence.
Masha was on a talk show on the TV a year ago where told that nobody forced her to undress or pose. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EkiEQF1pB9w

`ffmpeg â€¦ -movflags faststart`

1592964791_14cTEgRAd2nzUgLHkWNXwJ4E8Ue5m.body:
You video file needs to be prepared specifically for web. It has to be H.264 in mp4 container, with MOOV atom in the beginning of the file (so-called 'fast start'). Audio should be either mp3 or aac.

You can produce such files with ffmpeg: `ffmpeg -i input.mkv -map v:0 -map a:0 -c:v libx264 -c:a libmp3lame -crf 25 -b:a 192k -movflags faststart output.mp4`
webm with vp8/vp9 video and vorbis/opus audio is fine too.
